description: From Middle English crampe, from Old French crampe (“cramp”), from Frankish *krampa (“cramp”), from Proto-Germanic *krampō (“cramp, clasp”). Distant relative of English crop.

adjectives.description: cramp (comparative more cramp, superlative most cramp)

entries.meaning: A painful contraction of a muscle which cannot be controlled.
examples: the cramp also that divers nights gripeth him in his legs.

entries.meaning: A clamp for carpentry or masonry.
A piece of wood having a curve corresponding to that of the upper part of the instep, on which the upper leather of a boot is stretched to give it the requisite shape.

verbs.description: cramp (third-person singular simple present cramps, present participle cramping, simple past and past participle cramped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) (of a muscle) To contract painfully and uncontrollably.
(transitive) To affect with cramps or spasms.
examples: The collar of the tunic scratched my neck, the steel helmet made my head ache, and the puttees cramped my leg muscles.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To prohibit movement or expression of.
(transitive) To restrain to a specific physical position, as if with a cramp.
examples: You're going to need to cramp the wheels on this hill.

entries.meaning: To fasten or hold with, or as if with, a cramp iron.
(by extension) To bind together; to unite.
examples: The  […]  fabric of universal justice is well cramped and bolted together in all its parts.
